Research article Mono- and bi-nuclear phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts via simple Schiff-Base condensation for ethylene polymerization Jiangyan Li Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Yu Liu Data curation Formal analysis Investigation a b Hongliang Mu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a ⁎ Zhongbao Jian Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Renmin Street 5625, Changchun 130022, China State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Renmin Street 5625 Changchun 130022 China State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Renmin Street 5625, Changchun 130022, China b School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract In catalytic olefin polymerization, a significant amount of effort has been invested to modify either phosphine substituent or ligand backbone in recently advanced phosphine-phenolate [P,O] neutral nickel catalysts. Unlike other commonly used ligands like phenoxy-imines [N,O] and α-diimines [N,N], [P,O] ligands often require a laborious synthesis technique, which has hindered the rational design of ligand structures and the development of new catalysts. Here we present a novel and effective strategy for creating catalysts using [N,O,P] hybrid ligands. The substituent adjacent to the phenoxy group can be efficiently modified through straightforward Schiff-base condensation reactions with various amines that have established synthetic routes and diverse structures. This process results in the preparation of a series of highly active [P,O] nickel catalysts (up to 1.7 × 107 g mol-1h−1) that are capable of producing ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) (M w = 243.7 × 104 g/mol) in ethylene polymerization. The additional binding site greatly facilitates modulation of catalytic properties by additives, and parameters such as catalytic activity, polymer molecular weight, and polymer branching can be tuned in this way. Furthermore, binuclear [P,O] neutral nickel catalysts for olefin polymerization are synthesized for the first time using a sequence of diamines. The strategy presented in this work greatly improves the efficiency for the design and synthesis of [P,O] nickel and related catalysts. These findings will be advantageous for future catalyst design and screening. Keywords Phosphine-phenolate Neutral nickel catalyst Binuclear catalyst Ethylene polymerization UHMWPE Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalysts play a pivotal role in the production of commercial polyolefins. While Ziegler-Natta and (non)metallocene catalysts derived from early transition metals have traditionally dominated the industrial landscape,[1–5] recent decades have seen a surge of interest in late transition metal catalysts due to their distinctive properties.[6–10] This focus was sparked by groundbreaking research on Fe, Co, Ni, and Pd catalysts[11–16] which have been fine-tuned and greatly enhanced over the subsequent three decades.[17–25] Palladium catalysts, especially those based on α-diimine and phosphine-sulfonate ligands, have exhibited remarkable capabilities for the direct copolymerization of olefins with numerous polar monomers.[6,26] Consequently, nickel catalysts have also captured significant interest, owing to the high natural abundance of nickel and the cost-effectiveness of their feedstocks.[20,21,25,27–29] The active centers of nickel catalysts can vary from neutral to cationic, depending on the selection of ligands and precursors employed. The classic SHOP catalysts are a well-known example of neutral nickel catalysts that have been used in catalytic oligomerization reactions and also the copolymerization of olefins with norbornene derivatives or long-chain comonomers.[30–33] In recent years, there has been a renewed interest in these catalysts due to their ability to produce high molecular weight copolymers of ethylene with challenging monomers,[34–40] as well as their application in aqueous media for the production of nanoparticle dispersions.[41,42]. For salicylaldimine neutral nickel catalysts, it is well known that a bulky group in ortho-phenoxy position is crucial for making a highly active catalyst and for producing a high molecular weight polymer;[11] however, for phosphine-phenolate nickel catalysts, the catalytic performance is largely determined by the phosphine substituents, and diverse substitutions have been reported (examples see Chart 1 a).[34–41,43–45] Conversely, given that there aren't many viable substitution patterns, the impact of the ortho-phenoxy substituent in these catalysts is relatively hazy. Shimizu reported copolymerization results using catalyst with different ortho substituents and drew conclusion that aromatic substituents give a better performance regarding catalyst activity (e.g., -C6F5 vs - t Bu, 3.90 × 105 vs 1.73 × 105 g mol-1h−1), no effect on ethylene homopolymerization was reported in this work;[40] A series of simple substituents were introduced to the ortho-position of the phenolate of some nickel methyl(aryl) pyridine complexes, electron-withdrawing and bulky groups tend to afford highly active catalysts (up to 2.4 × 107 g mol-1h−1); however, some contradictions were observed in terms of their influence on polymer molecular weight (t-Bu vs C6F5, CF3 vs CH3), which signifies the complexity of substitution effects.[34,44,46] Additional binding sites (phosphines or polyethylene glycol) were also introduced to the phosphine-phenolate nickel catalysts, which facilitates the electronic and steric manipulation by coordinative additives.[38,47,48] Phosphine-naphtholate nickel catalysts were reported to be active for ethylene (co)polymerizations, and the substituent adjacent to the phenoxy group also influences the catalyst initiation and polymer molecular weight.[38,49]. The diversity of combinations between ortho substituents and phosphine moieties results in complex and enigmatic effects on catalysis. Therefore, to expedite the screening and exploration and facilitate the development of novel high-performance catalysts, it is crucial to devise efficient techniques for accessing related ligand frameworks. Currently, synthesizing the abovementioned phosphine-phenolate nickel complexes requires the introduction of ortho-phenoxy aryl substituents via metal-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions; in the case of alkyl substituted catalysts, the specified substituted starting materials must be commercially available. However, both methods lack the desired flexibility. In this work, we present neutral nickel catalysts bearing a ligand framework containing both imine and phosphine donors for ethylene polymerization, based on our experience in developing neutral nickel catalysts bearing [N,O] and [P,O] ligands. This design allows a facile modification of the environment around the ortho position of the phenoxy moiety by convenient Schiff-base condensations and potential modulation by various additives. Furthermore, by using different diamines as the starting materials, binuclear phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts could be constructed, providing new possibilities for potential binuclear effects. 2 Results and discussion To access target ligands L1-L4, the essential steps involve the synthesis of phosphine-phenol ligands that feature formaldehyde functionality (Scheme 1 ). We started from protected 2-bromo-4-tert-butyl-phenol, two rounds of lithiation were conducted, each followed by quenching with electrophiles chloride phosphines and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), respectively. This is followed by deprotection, leading to the formation of compounds CP1 and CP2 in moderate yields. After condensing with the corresponding anilines, pure ligands L1-L4 can be effortlessly isolated through simple filtration and washing with methanol and hexane. Upon treatment with sodium hydride to deprotonate and reaction with trans-NiPhCl(PPh3)2, pure nickel complexes Ni1-Ni4 can be obtained through recrystallization (Scheme 1). In the 31P NMR spectra of all four complexes, a distinct downfield shift relative to the free ligands is observed, exhibiting a peak around 20 ppm. This observation unequivocally suggests that it is the phosphorous atom, and not the nitrogen atom, that has effectively coordinated with the nickel center. The significant 2 J PP coupling constants, exceeding 280 Hz for Ni1, Ni2, Ni4, suggest the trans-arrangement of the phosphorous atoms in triphenylphosphine and chelate ligands (Figure S27, S30 and S36) In Ni3, only two singlets could be observed in 31P NMR spectrum, possibly due to signal overlapping (Figure S33). This configuration is also indicated by the doublet of doublets (2 J PC coupling constants around 30 Hz) at 140–150 ppm for all the four complexes, which is attributable to the ipso-carbon of nickel-phenyl group cis to the two phosphorous atoms (13C NMR spectra, see Figure S28, 31, 34 and 37). The solid-state structure of Ni4 was further identified by X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis (Fig. 1 ). A к2-P,O coordinated nickel complex with a square planar geometry around nickel center was confirmed, and the triphenylphosphine ligand is positioned trans to the phenolate moiety. As a к2-P,O rather than к2-N,O chelation is employed, the bulky N-aryl substituent and the ligand backbone are situated in the trans position relative to the C = N double bond. This configuration may result in reduced steric hindrance in the ortho-phenoxy position when using a smaller amine, which can be disadvantageous for catalyst initiation. In conventional neutral nickel catalysts, the ortho position of the phenoxy group is occupied by a simple alkyl or aryl substituent. These substituents serve to stabilize the complex and facilitate the dissociation of the labile ligand. Recently, [N,O,N] and [P,O,P][47,50] ligands have also been reported, in which the additional donor was installed to facilitate further modification through the coordination of cation additives. In this work, the [N,O,P] hybrid ligands were meticulously designed and synthesized. The [O,P] segment was primarily intended for coordination with the nickel center, while the nitrogen donor was responsible for catalyst modification. Without the addition of any co-catalyst, the catalytic performance of the new catalysts was evaluated for ethylene polymerization at various temperatures using 8 bar of ethylene. These catalysts, except for Ni1 with 2-methoxyphenyl as the phosphine substituents, all have phenyl/2,6-dimethoxylbiphenyl substituted phosphines and exhibit high catalytic activities (>106 g mol-1h−1) as single-component catalysts (Table 1 ). The polymer molecular weights achieved with Ni1 catalysis are significantly lower (<104 g/mol), similar to the results reported previously for catalysts containing the same phosphine groups.[51] However, the lower activity seems to suggest that the 2,6-diisopropyl substitution is not bulky enough to stabilize the catalytic active center due to the small phosphine substituent in L1. At lower temperatures, Ni1 shows particularly low activity (Table 1, entries 1 and 2, ∼104 g mol-1h−1), presumably due to the neighboring groups being insufficiently bulky, failing to promote the departure of labile ligands to form the active center. Catalysts Ni1 and Ni2 share the same ortho-phenoxy group, and it is observed that both polymer molecular weight and catalytic activity have been greatly improved by bulky phosphine substituent (Table 1, entries 1–5 vs 6–10). The much higher polymer branching (up to 14 brs/1000C, Table 1, entry 5) and low melting points observed (<125.1 °C, Table 1, entries 1–4) using Ni1 also indicates a greatly suppressed chain-walking by using larger phosphine substituents for catalysts Ni2-Ni4. Catalysts Ni2-Ni4 share the same phosphine substitution (phenyl/2,6-dimethoxylbiphenyl) and different ortho-phenoxy substituents. The catalytic polymerization results in Table 1 can be more visually intuitive when presented in the form of a line graph in Fig. 2 . In terms of catalytic activity, with the increase in polymerization temperature, these catalysts all display stable changes from 30 to 50 °C and are at a low level (Table 1, entries 6, 7, 11, 12, and Fig. 2-left), indicative of a process of labile ligand departure for all these catalysts. Large substituents are clearly advantageous due to easier dissociation of labile ligands, resulting in higher catalytic activity at low polymerization temperature (Table 1, entries 6, 11, 15). With further temperature increase, the equilibrium shifts toward dissociation, and catalytic activity greatly increases for all the three catalysts (Table 1, entries 8, 13). With further heating, activities using Ni3 and Ni4 begin to decline, possibly due to partial deactivation of the catalyst (Table 1, entries 14, 18). In contrast, catalyst Ni2 exhibits its peak activity at a higher temperature (90 °C, Table 1, entry 9), which may be rationalized by considering that its labile group is more resistant to dissociation due to the smaller ortho-phenoxy substitution. In terms of polymer molecular weight, the varying patterns for three catalysts with different polymerization temperatures can be observed. At lower temperatures (30 °C), the catalyst with significant steric hindrance produces high-molecular-weight polymers (Table 1, entries 6, 11 vs entry 15). However, as the temperature rises, the performance of Ni2-Ni4 converges. For instance, Ni4 can produce polymers with a weight-average molecular weight (M w) above 70.0 × 104 g/mol at low temperatures (Table 1, entry 15), while Ni2 under the same conditions can only achieve a M w of 33.3 × 104 g/mol (Table 1, entry 6). At 90 °C, the three lines intersect at M w of around 10.0 × 104 g/mol (Fig. 2-right). This suggests a possible scenario where the three catalysts form the same catalytically active species at 90 °C due to the decomposition of the Schiff-bases. To gather relevant information, we dissolved catalyst Ni4 in toluene and heated it at a higher temperature of 110 °C for 1.5 h. The NMR spectra (Figure S50 and Figure S51) of the resulting material showed weak peaks of ligand L4, and no evidence for the formation of aldehyde functional groups or other nickel complexes were identified. Therefore, the similar catalytic behavior for Ni2-Ni4 in terms of the molecular weight of the resultant polymer may be attributed to the free rotation of the ortho-substituted Schiff-base group at higher temperatures. It is discovered that at a low temperature of 30 °C, the polymers obtained by using Ni2 and Ni3 exhibit a broader molecular weight distribution, with values of 2.71 (Entry 6) and 2.99 (Entry 11) respectively. This observation can be attributed to the equilibrium between the coordination and dissociation of pyridine. As the temperature increases, the molecular weight distribution narrows down to approximately 2.0. The larger steric hindrance of Ni4 prevents the observed phenomenon, presumably due to the easier detachment of pyridine at 30 °C. This finding aligns with the enhanced activity of Ni4 at low temperatures (Entry 15). It is also evident that under 30 °C, the amount of polymer obtained from Ni4 increases over time, and the catalytic activity does not significantly decay (Table 1, entries 16, 19, 20), indicating good catalyst lifetime at this temperature. By utilizing the unique characteristic of achieving polymer high molecular weight at 30 °C using catalyst Ni4, UHMWPE can be obtained by prolonging the polymerization time, even though this catalyst does not exhibit obvious living characteristics (Entries 19 and 20). Interestingly, while phosphine-phenolate nickel catalysts with bulky substituents are renowned for producing high-molecular-weight linear polyethylene, achieving molecular weight with ultrahigh levels (M w > 106 g/mol) has been challenging. Relevant reports have only recently emerged, achieved through elaborate electronic and steric control[34,46] or by catalyzing polymerization in an aqueous media.[42] This further suggests the feasibility of enhancing such catalysts through straightforward Schiff-base chemistry. Taking into account the presence of the uncoordinated imine group in the catalysts, it is evident that it not only exhibits steric effects but also possesses coordination capabilities. Consequently, the performance of these catalysts can be readily tuned by the addition of additives that interact with them. Actually the additional donor sites have previously been taken advantage in catalyst heterogenization[52–55] and allosteric regulation.[56–58] Recently, Do[51,59,60] and Tonks[61,62] also developed a series of ligand structures that are amenable to modification by binding alkali cations or Lewis-acidic salts. Especially, Mecking and Agapie have presented valuable insights into the modulation that occurs when proton[50] and Lewis acid[47] bind in [N,O,N] and [P,O,P] nickel systems, respectively. In this study, we also conducted catalytic polymerization experiments in the presence of various additives, utilizing Ni4 as the catalyst. The results of these experiments are summarized in Table 2 , and Fig. 3 provides a more direct representation of the effects of these additives. A proton donor, [H(OEt2)2]+[B(C6F5)4]– (HB), was introduced to reorient the arylimine group in catalyst Ni4, and bring it closer to the nickel center. Simultaneously, protonation of the catalyst was done to control the electron density at the metal center. The polymerization results indicate a sharp increase in catalytic activity (1 order of magnitude higher, up to 1.65 × 107 g mol-1h−1) due to the introduction of the proton source (Table 2, entries 1, 2 vs Table 1, entries 15, 16). Concurrently, the molecular weight of the resulting polymer is almost 2 orders of magnitude lower (e.g. Table 1, entry 16 vs Table 2, entry 2). The observed sharp decrease in molecular weight cannot solely be attributed to the intensified chain transfer due to the excessive reaction heat released, since the polymer produced by the same catalyst (Ni4) at 90 °C (as indicated in Table 1, entry 18) still possesses a molecular weight above 104 g/mol. The polymer branching density has also been elevated, surpassing even that achieved with catalyst Ni1 containing small phosphine substituents (e.g., Table 1, entry 1 vs Table 2, entry 1; 5 vs 10 brs/1000C). This can be explained by the fact that protonation stabilizes β-agostic species by significantly lowering the electron density at the metal center, which promotes β-H elimination over chain growth. Similar phenomenon was also observed in [N,O,N] nickel catalyst using [H(OEt2)2]+[BArF 4]– (ArF = 3,5-(CF3)2C6H3).[50] The polymer from entry 2, Table 2 exhibits a predominantly methyl branching pattern, with minor ethyl branches also discernible (Figure S98). [Si(CH3)3]2NLi (LiHMDS) was chosen as an additive during the polymerization process. This lithium regent was previously used to deprotonate the β‑oxo-δ-diimine nickel complex and interact with the secondary binding pocket to give a Ni-Li heterobimetallic complex.[63] However, in our case, we do not expect any protonation to occur. NMR experiment (Figure S52 and Figure S53) shows that the addition of LiHMDS to catalyst Ni4 results in removal of the PPh3 ligand, and the formation of a new complex containing N(SiMe3)2 ligand (0.51 and 0.67 ppm in 1H NMR spectrum, Figure S52). This indicates that the lithium cation (Li+) of the additive may have interaction with the [N, O] part of this catalyst. Contrary to the role of the proton donor, when 10 equivalents of LiHMDS was added, the catalytic activity slightly decreased, while the molecular weight of the resulting polymer increased (Table 2, entries 3 and 4). The underlying reason for this observation remains to be investigated. The addition of 5 equivalents of Ni(COD)2 did not have any significant effect on the catalytic performance (Table 2, entries 5 and 6). Under these conditions, extending the polymerization time to 120 min resulted in linear polyethylene with a molecular weight exceeding 200.0 × 104 g/mol (Table 2, entry 6). When 10 equivalents of the Lewis acid ZnBr2 were added, there was only a slight decrease in both the molecular weight of the polymer and the catalytic activity (Table 2, entry 7 vs Table 1, entry 13). This contrasts with reports on [N,O,N] nickel catalysts, where a very low molecular weight polymer was obtained due to a reduced β-H elimination barrier, especially for the к2-N,O bimetallic catalysts.[61] 1H NMR experiments (Figure S54) demonstrate that the addition of ZnBr2 generates a novel set of signals attributed to -OMe, -Me, and - t Bu groups, suggestive of a productive interaction between ZnBr2 and the catalyst. Previous reports have indicated that Lewis acidic ZnCl2 can abstract pyridine from a nickel center.[62] In our study, the absence of signals associated with free PPh3 might be explained by the coordination of excess ZnBr2 with PPh3. However, further insights are limited as the 31P NMR spectrum is unavailable, presumably due to the formation of paramagnetic impurities. In contrast to the observation made with HB as the additive (Figure S98), the polymer branching is hardly discernible in the 13C NMR spectrum of the resulting polymer obtained in the presence of ZnBr2 (Table 2, entry 7, Figure S99). It is often reported that multinuclear catalysts exhibit superior performance compared to mononuclear catalysts, attributed to potential cooperative effects between the metal centers that are confined in close proximity.[64] Multinuclear neutral nickel catalysts have been proven to exhibit superior performance in the preparation of topological polyolefins, improving catalyst thermostability, enhancing catalytic activity and the comonomer incorporation.[65–80] Despite renewed interest in phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts, there have been no reports on the construction of binuclear variants based on these catalysts. This is likely due to the intricate nature of the synthesis, as the low stability of trivalent phosphorous and the complexity of the reactions pose significant challenges. Considering the unique features of this family of nickel catalysts, the development of binuclear catalysts is of significant interest. Starting from compound CP2, catalyst derivation can be easily conducted taking advantage of the reactivity of formaldehyde functionality without affecting other moieties in ligands, which is potentially useful in the design of binuclear catalysts. Diamines with different steric hindrance were thus used to condense with CP2 to give ligands L5 and L6 in high yields. To explore the possibility of confining two metal centers in close proximity, ligand L7 was also designed and synthesized from a bridged diamine 4,4′-(9,9-dimethylxanthene-4,5-diyl)-bis(2,6-dimethylaniline). These ligands were also applied in the reaction with nickel source complexes. For easy purification and analysis of the NMR spectra, the binuclear catalysts were obtained by the reaction of ligands with (tmeda)NiMe2 rather than trans-NiPhCl(PPh3)2, and Ni2′ from the same synthetic route was also synthesized for comparison (Scheme 2 ). Table 3 compares the catalytic performance of the mononuclear catalyst Ni2′ with three newly developed binuclear catalysts Ni5-Ni7. Catalyst Ni6 has a structure that is highly similar to Ni2′, except that it has a binuclear structure linked at the distal end of the imine groups. Across a range of temperatures, the binuclear catalyst Ni6 consistently exhibits higher activity (Table 3, entries 5–7 vs entries 13–15), except at 90 °C, where it is outperformed by the mononuclear analogue Ni2′ (Table 3, entry 8 vs entry 16). This can be attributed to the smaller steric hindrance of Ni2′, enabling the release of the labile ligand at elevated temperatures. In general, the binuclear catalyst produces polymers with higher molecular weight and reduced branching (Ni6 vs Ni2′, Table 3, entries 5–8 vs entries 13–16). Given the significant distance between the two nickel centers, these outcomes are probably affected by steric effects introduced by the diimine linker. Catalysts Ni5 and Ni6, both possessing a binuclear structure, differ solely in the steric hindrance of the bridging group. The two catalysts demonstrate comparable catalytic activity, with the slightly less hindered one typically yielding polymers of lower molecular weight but similar branching density (Table 3, entries 1–4 vs 5–8). The binuclear catalysts Ni6 and Ni7 have identical substituents (isopropyl groups) at their proximal ends, while the distal bridges differ, resulting in distinct distances between the two nickel centers. Given the increased probability of proximity between the two nickel centers caused by the 9,9-dimethylxanthene linkage, the labile pyridine group is more readily detachable for Ni7. A shift in equilibrium towards dissociation allows the catalyst to show high activity at lower temperatures. However, this comes at a cost of weakened stabilizing effect of the pyridine ligand. This may explain why Ni7 maintains higher activity within the 30 °C to 70 °C range (Table 3, entries 5–7 vs 9–11), yet the catalytic activity declines at higher temperature (Table 3, entries 8 vs 12). Of course, the close proximity of the nickel centers for Ni7 may also increases the likelihood of bisligation deactivation. Moreover, a remarkable observation is that the polymer synthesized using Ni7 exhibits higher branching at lower temperatures (Table 3, entry 9, 30 °C, 6 brs/1000C), which diminishes as the temperature rises (Table 3, entry 10, 50 °C, 3 brs/1000C; entry 11, 70 °C, 2 brs/1000C). The underlying cause of this behavior remains uncertain and might be attributed to interactions between the closely situated metal centers. This finding suggests that modifying catalyst performance can be achieved by designing distinct ortho-imine bridging groups, and further exploration in this area is currently underway. 3 Conclusions In summary, phosphine-phenol ligands containing pendant imine groups were used in this work for the construction of phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts. The synthetic route to these new catalysts was through easy Schiff-base condensation, greatly facilitating the derivation of related catalysts. The introduction of the free N-donor in this study aimed to achieve, and indeed successfully fulfilled, threefold objectives: 1) For the modification of environment at ortho-phenoxy position. Substituents with different steric effects can be easily introduced to this position by Schiff-base condensation of the aldehyde-functionalized phosphine-phenol with amines. Differed catalytic performance was observed and UHMWPE was obtained by using the bulkiest new catalyst (Ni4). 2) For catalyst modulation by additives. Ni(COD)2, ZnBr2, [H(OEt2)2]+[B(C6F5)4]- and [Si(CH3)3]2NLi were used respectively as additive for tuning the catalytic performance. The effect of proton source was the most prominent, resulting in greatly improved catalytic activity and decreased polymer molecular weight. 3) For the construction of multinuclear catalysts. Starting from diamines, binuclear catalysts were designed and successfully synthesized. Currently, while no significant and clear cooperative effects for the binuclear catalysts are observed, this work presents an efficient method for synthesizing multinuclear phosphine-phenolate nickel catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, these are the first binuclear phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts for olefin polymerization ever reported. We are designing new Schiff-base linkers to pursue synergistic work of the metal centers. These results demonstrate that the Schiff-base method for catalyst construction is versatile, offering numerous opportunities for the advancement of polymerization catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In catalytic olefin polymerization, a significant amount of effort has been invested to modify either phosphine substituent or ligand backbone in recently advanced phosphine-phenolate [P,O] neutral nickel catalysts. Unlike other commonly used ligands like phenoxy-imines [N,O] and α-diimines [N,N], [P,O] ligands often require a laborious synthesis technique, which has hindered the rational design of ligand structures and the development of new catalysts. Here we present a novel and effective strategy for creating catalysts using [N,O,P] hybrid ligands. The substituent adjacent to the phenoxy group can be efficiently modified through straightforward Schiff-base condensation reactions with various amines that have established synthetic routes and diverse structures. This process results in the preparation of a series of highly active [P,O] nickel catalysts (up to 1.7 × 107 g mol-1h−1) that are capable of producing ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) (M w = 243.7 × 104 g/mol) in ethylene polymerization. The additional binding site greatly facilitates modulation of catalytic properties by additives, and parameters such as catalytic activity, polymer molecular weight, and polymer branching can be tuned in this way. Furthermore, binuclear [P,O] neutral nickel catalysts for olefin polymerization are synthesized for the first time using a sequence of diamines. The strategy presented in this work greatly improves the efficiency for the design and synthesis of [P,O] nickel and related catalysts. These findings will be advantageous for future catalyst design and screening.
coredata.dc:title: Mono- and bi-nuclear phosphine-phenolate neutral nickel catalysts via simple Schiff-Base condensation for ethylene polymerization
